newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African stock market closing report.
newsitem.headline: S.African stock market closing report.

text.p: The easing of foreign exchange controls on South African individuals on Tuesday was welcomed by shares, lifting the industrial index to a new closing high despite a tumble in Murray & Roberts.
But niggling worries that the move, which allows individuals a once-off 200,000 rand offshore investment, may weaken the rand boosted rand-hedge stock Richemont to a 1997 best.
Analysts described the relaxation, which forms part of government's phased removal of exchange controls, as a non-event and in line with authorities' expectations.
"Its been exceptionally quiet. A lot of enquiries but a non-event," Autrey Wilke, general manager of international treasury trading at Absa Bank, told Reuters.

But dealers said caution was evident in the market and investors were seen adopting a wait-and-see attitude on Wednesday, eyeing the rand which earlier weakened over 1.5 cents although retracing back to overnight levels in late trade.
"A lot of people are just sitting on the sidelines to see first how much money will flow out," a dealer said.
Richemont added over three percent to 69.00 rand and pushed it to top the list of value traders by notching up 67 million rand's worth.
Engineering to construction firm Murray & Roberts was one of the biggest losers, shedding 15 percent or 165 cents to a new year low of 900 cents after a profit warning.
The industrial index headed north, notching up its second consecutive closing high, to end up 18.2 points at 8,808.7.
Dealers said stock gains later on Tuesday were also helped by a rally on the bond and share futures markets, which were both pleased by the recovery in the rand.
The industrial September futures contract was up over one hundred points in late trade to last trade at 8,680/88 from 8,579, lifting the all-share contract to 6,844/55 from 6,791.
Dealers said stock market turnover, which at the day's end was over 600 million rand, was boosted by large offshore trades in several shares by brokerage Smith Borkum Hare.
Dealers said the trades, in stocks including Rentsure, Omnia and Engen, appeared to be part of a programme deal with an offshore fund.

Gold shares overall added 3.6 points to 968.6, taking heart initially from the weaker rand and shrugging off bullion's fall to fresh 4 -1/4 year lows. The September gold future was firmer at 675/85 from 670.
Altogether the spot all-share index was hardly moved at 7,420.1, a gain of 0.1 of a point.
Declining issues outpaced advancers by 193 to 159 and new highs and lows were evenly matched at 31.
Among other features, Knights added five cents to 33 cents on talks about the formation of a new company which will buy Knights' assets were continuing.

Randgold, weighed recently by the poor gold price, a lower-than-expected listing for its resources unit in London and expectations of the worst gold mining quarter ever, added five percent or 100 cents to 21 rand.
Stantronic added eight cents to 124 cents on news it was in unspecified talks.
-- Nicole Mordant, Johannesburg newsroom 27 11 482 1003
